unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Traffic Accidents
question_text:
A traffic engineer is curious if elderly drivers are more or less likely to get into accidents than teenage drivers.
The engineer randomly sampled $100$ teenage drivers and $100$ drivers more than $80$ years old, asking both groups if they have gotten in an accident in the last year.
A hypothesis test of $ { p }_{ 1 }= { p }_{ 2 }$ vs. ${ p }_{ 1 } â‰  { p }_{ 2 }$ gives a test statistic $z = 1.13$.
Assuming conditions for inference have been met, what conclusion can be made?

choices.text: Strong evidence exists to suggest that younger and older drivers are equally likely to get into an accident.
Weak evidence exists to suggest that younger and older drivers are equally likely to get into an accident.
There is insufficient information to come to any conclusion.
There is strong evidence of a difference in accident rates between older and younger drivers.
There is insufficient evidence to conclude older and younger drivers have different accident rates.

solution:
With a test statistic of $z = 1.13$, use the standard normal table to find $p (z > 1.13) = 1-0.8708 = 0.1292$.

This is a two-sided test, so double the $p$-value: $0.1292 \times 2 = 0.2584$.

Since this is a high $p$-value at all common alpha levels of $1\%, 5\%$, and $10\%$, this constitutes as insufficient evidence to reject $H_0$.

Therefore, this is not enough evidence to say older and younger drivers have different accident rates.

Note that any high $p$-value cannot be thought of as strong, moderate, or weak evidence. Also, note that one can come to the conclusion that no evidence of change exists since $p$ is so large.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
